seed: I get a tight chest before meetings and I avoid speaking, then I regret it all day.

transcript.content: I get a tight chest before meetings and I avoid speaking, then I regret it all day.
There may be a rule in the background that says if you don't speak up, you'll feel regret later.  What makes you think that silence is the only way to avoid feeling regret?

I guess I just feel like when I don’t say anything, I can avoid confrontation or making things worse. It’s like, if I keep quiet, maybe things will just work themselves out. But then, yeah, I do end up feeling pretty bad later for not saying what I really think. It’s frustrating because I don’t want to regret not speaking, but then speaking feels so risky.
There may be a rule in the background that says silence is always safer than speaking up.  What makes you think that's true?

I suppose it’s just how things have always felt for me. Growing up, there were a lot of times when speaking up led to arguments or made things worse, so I learned to just keep my mouth shut. It seems easier that way, you know? But deep down, I’m scared that if I do speak up, people won’t like what I say or will think less of me.
There may be a rule in the background that says speaking your mind always leads to negative consequences.  What evidence supports that rule, and what evidence might challenge it?

Yeah, I guess I have seen moments where speaking up led to really tough situations. Like, last time I tried to voice my opinion during a team meeting, it turned into this awkward silence and I felt so embarrassed. But then, I think about times when I’ve shared something and it was received well, like that one time my friend actually thanked me for being honest. It’s just that those
There may be a rule in the background that says speaking up always leads to negative outcomes.  What evidence supports that rule versus the times you've been met with positive responses?

I mean, I guess there’s some truth to that. A lot of the negative experiences stand out more, you know? It’s like they stick in my mind and make me worry about what could go wrong every time I think about speaking up. But still, I can’t totally ignore the good moments—those times were nice, and I felt like I connected with others. It's just hard to
There may be a rule in the background that says "positive experiences are less important than negative ones."  How does that idea fit with your experience of those good moments?

That’s an interesting way to phrase it. I definitely do tend to remember the negative stuff more vividly. It’s almost like they drown out the positive experiences, even though they’re there. I think part of me feels like if I focus too much on the good moments, I might end up setting myself up for disappointment. It feels safer to brace myself for the worst, which... I don’t
There may be a rule in the background that says happiness is fleeting and therefore not worth investing in.  What evidence do you have for this rule?

Yeah, I guess that does resonate with me. There have been times where when I was really happy, something would happen to bring me back down, like losing a job or having a fight with someone. It’s like I start to think... if I allow myself to feel too good, I’m setting myself up for a fall. So, maybe it’s easier to just keep my happiness in check
There may be a rule in the background that says happiness is fleeting and therefore not worth pursuing wholeheartedly.  What evidence have you noticed supports this rule?

I mean, that sounds about right. There have definitely been moments where I've thought, “This won’t last,” like a good day at work or a fun hangout with friends. It’s almost like I can see the clouds rolling in, you know? I remember times when I was really excited about something, and then it all just crumbled. So, I think I’ve started to believe
There may be a rule operating here that says positive experiences are inherently temporary.  What evidence do you have for this rule, and how might it affect your enjoyment of good moments?

Yeah, that definitely sounds like something I’ve been holding on to. I mean, looking back, I can think of a few times when I was really happy, and then something would happen that just changed everything—like someone moving away or plans falling through. It makes it hard to really enjoy the good moments when I feel like they can disappear so quickly. I guess it keeps me from fully embracing
There may be a rule in the background that says happiness is fragile and needs to be guarded.  What evidence do you have for that rule?

Hmm, I suppose I can think of a few moments. Like when my family went through that rough patch, and we had really good days that felt like they were lifting us up, but then something would happen—a fight or some bad news—and it felt like we were right back where we started. It just showed me that happiness didn’t always stick around. I guess I see it as a pattern
There may be a rule in the background that says good times are temporary and setbacks are inevitable.  What evidence do you have for that rule?

Yeah, I think I do have a lot of evidence for that. Like, every time something good happens, it feels like I’m just waiting for the other shoe to drop. There have been breakups, job losses, and just moments where things fell apart when I thought I was finally getting ahead. It’s almost like I can predict the bad after the good, and it just makes me feel

cbt_context.patient_text: I get a tight chest before meetings and I avoid speaking, then I regret it all day.

automatic_thoughts: I regret it all day

concepts.term: Social phobia, fear of public speaking (disorder)
